info.title: Installing Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP1
info.subtitle: For x86-64 Architectures

abstract.para: Oracle WebLogic Server 12c R2 is a reliable application server for building and deploying enterprise Java EE applications with support for new features for lowering cost of operations, improving performance, enhancing scalability and supporting the Oracle Applications portfolio. WebLogic Server Java EE applications are based on standardized, modular components. Oracle WebLogic Server provides a complete set of services for those modules and handles many details of application behavior automatically, without requiring programming.

SUSE Linux Enterprise Server provides Oracle customers a scalable platform for demanding workloads and applications. Oracle and SUSE have teamed up to enable Linux in enterprises and have created world-class solutions that offer real-grid benefits for IT data centers today. This document provides the details for installing Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP1.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This document provides the details for installing Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP1. Details are provided for the Intel x86-64 versions of both Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12. Similar steps apply to other platforms (x86, ia64, IBM z Systems, etc.). If you encounter issues or have general questions, please post your query to suse-oracle@listx.novell.com.
The official Oracle product documentation is available at:

sect1.title: System Requirements and Specifications
sect1.para: The following paragraphs provide details about the hardware and software requirements that need to be met to install Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 on top of SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP1. They also contain the specification of the test environment.

row.entry: Approximately twice the size of RAM

listitem.para: CPU: 2 * Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2630 v3 @ 2.40GHz

sect2.title: Installing &sls; 12
sect2.para: Install &sls; 12 on your testing machine. To do so, follow the instructions in the official &sls; documentation at
In YaST, select the patterns you need. Make sure you select the patterns and packages required to run Oracle products (for example orarun).
After the installation of &sls;, the following information about the operating system and the kernel version is displayed:

sect2.title: Installing Java
sect2.para: Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 (12.2.1) requires JDK version 1.8. Log in to the target system (&sls; 12 64-bit operating system) as a non-administration user. Download the Java SE Development Kit 8 (jdk-8u91-linux- x64.tar.gz) from .
Set the environment variables JAVA_HOME and PATH to ensure the proper JDK version is installed and ready for use.

sect1.title: Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 Installation
sect1.para: The following sections explain how to perform your Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 installation.

sect2.title: Installing Oracle WebLogic Server Software
sect2.para: Log in to the target system (&sls; 12 64-bit operating system) as a non-administration user. Download the Oracle WebLogic Server 12cR2 (12.2.1) from .

note.title: Permissions
note.para: Ensure the installation user has the proper permissions to install and configure the software.

sect2.para: Go to the directory where you downloaded the installation program. Extract the contents of the .zip file fmw_12.2.1.0.0_wls_Disk1_1of1.zip) and launch the installation program by running java -jar fmw.xxxx.jar.
For the actual installation, follow the steps below:

step.para: Go to Installation Inventory Setup.

If this is your first Oracle installation on a host that is running &sls;, use the Oracle Fusion Middleware 12c Installation Inventory Setup screen to specify the location of the Oracle Central Inventory Directory and Operating System Group Name. Click OK to continue.
Proceed to Welcome.
Review the information on this screen carefully to be sure you have performed all the necessary prerequisites. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Auto Updates.
Select the option Skip Auto Updates", to skip this screen. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Installation Location.
Type the full path of the directory into the Oracle Home field. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Installation Type.
Use this screen to determine the type of installation you want to perform, then click Next to continue.
Proceed to Prerequisite Checks.
The Prerequisite Checks results will be shown as above. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Security Updates .
If you wish to register your installation, enter your e-mail address and your My Oracle Support password.
If you wish to decline registration, deselect I wish to receive security updates via My Oracle Support and confirm your choice.
Proceed to Installation Summary .

This screen contains a list of the feature sets you selected for your installation, along with the approximate amount of disk space to be used by the feature sets once the installation is complete. Check the information, then click Install to continue.
Proceed to Installation Progress.
This screen shows the progress of the installation. When the progress bar reaches 100 percent, the installation is complete. Click Finish to continue.
Proceed to Installation Complete.
This screen appears at the conclusion of the installation. Select the optionAutomatically Launch the Configuration Wizard, then click Finish to exit the installer.

sect2.title: Creating and Configuring the WebLogic Domain
sect2.para: To start the domain configuration, you can choose from two option

listitem.para: From the last-shown screen Installation Complete, you can automatically launch the WebLogic Configuration Wizard through the option Automatically Launch the Configuration Wizard.
You can also navigate to the directory ORACLE_HOME/oracle_common/common/bin and start the WebLogic Server Configuration Wizard by running the command ./config.sh.

sect2.para: To set up your configuration, follow the steps below:

step.para: Go to Configuration Type.
Select the option Create a New Domain and specify the Domain home directory in the Domain Location field. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Templates.
On the Templates screen select Basic WebLogic Server Domain which is pre-selected by default, and WebLogic Coherence Cluster Extension for the configuration. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Administrator Account.
Specify the user name and password for the default WebLogic Administrator account for the domain. Click Next to continue.
Proceed to Domain Mode and JDK.
Select Development in the Domain Mode field and the Oracle HotSpot in the JDK field. Click Next to continue.

sect3.title: Preparation
sect3.para: Log in to the SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 64-bit OS as a non-admin user. Download the Oracle Database 12c Release 1 (12.1.0.2.0) for Linux x86-64.
Extract grid.zip and run the installer './runInstaller' from Database ShipHome.

sect3.title: Installation
sect3.para: For the actual installation, follow the steps below:

step.para: Select Configure Security Updates
Provide your e-mail address to be informed of security issues, then click Next to continue.
Select Installation Option.
Choose the option Install database software only, then click Next to continue.
Select Grid Installation Options.
Choose the option Oracle Real Application Clusters database installation, then click Next to continue.
Go to Nodes Selection to select from the list of nodes.
Select all nodes in the cluster, then click Next to continue.
Select Product Languages.
Select all languages, then click Next to continue.
Select Database Edition.
Choose the option Enterprise Edition, then click Next to continue.
Specify the Installation Location.
Fill in the Oracle base and the Software location as shown above, then click Next to continue.
Define the privileged Operating System Groups.
The priviledged Operating System groups are selected by default. Click Next to continue.
Perform the Prerequisite Checks .
Perform the pre-check as shown above; to recheck the system. Click Fix&Check Again to continue.
Follow the prompts. Manually run the fixup script as root user on each node, then click OK.
You should see the following output:
step.screen: c2n1 ~ #: /tmp/CVU_12.1.0.2.0_oracle/runfixup.sh All Fix-up operations were completed successfully.
step.para: Check the Fixup Results here:
Check the Verification Results here:
Select the option Ignore All, then click Next to continue.
Review the Summary.
If you see the installation summary as shown above, click Install to continue.
Select Install Product.
While the product loads, a window pops up where you can execute the configuration scripts.
Execute root.sh as the root user in each cluster node, then click OK to continue.
You will see the following output:

sect3.title: Create ASM Disk Group
sect3.para: Use the ASM Configuration Assistant to create the ASM disk group for datafile storage.
Follow the instructions displayed on the screen.

sect3.title: Create Oracle RAC 12.1.0.2 Database
sect3.para: Perform the following steps to create your Oracle RAC 12.1.0.2 database by using the Database Configuration Assistant:

step.para: Select Database Operation.
Choose the option Create Database, then click Next to continue.
Select Creation Mode.
Choose the option Advanced Mode, then click Next to continue.
Select Database Template.
Select the type of database you want to configure, then click Next to continue.
Select Database Identification.
Fill in the Global Database Name as shown above, then click Next to continue.

note.title: Container Database
note.para: Oracle Database 12C supports the creation of a Container Database. This means you can also create a Container Database depending on your needs.

step.para: Select Database Placement.
Review the Server Pools information as shown above. Click Next to continue.
Select Management Options.
Specify the management options for the database, then click Next to continue.
Select Database Credentials.
Specify the administrative password for the database users, then click Next to continue.
Select Storage Locations.
Specify the database files storage information as shown above, then click Next to continue.
Select Database Options.
According to your needs, specify whether to add the schemas to your database. Click Next to continue.
Select Initialization Parameters.
Choose the option Typical Settings and adjust the parameters to meet your requirements. Click Next to continue.
Select Creation Options.
Select the database creation options as shown above, then click Next to continue.
Perform the Prerequisite Checks.
Select the option Ignore All, then click Next to continue.
Review the Summary.
Review and check the information displayed in the Database Configuration Summary as shown above. Click Finish to continue.
Review the Progress Page.
The creation of your database is now progressing as shown above. Wait until the creation process is completed.
Proceed to Finish.
When the creation of the database is completed, some information is displayed on the screen as shown above. Click Close to close the screen.
Verify the database status and the configuration.

step.para: Verify the availability of your Oracle Enterprise Manager.

listitem.para: Edit the CV_ASUME_DISTID=SUSE11 parameter in database/stage/cvu/cv/admin/cvu_config & grid/stage/cvu/cv/admin/cvu_config
Apply Patch 20737462 to address CVU issues relating to the lack of reference data
Install libcap1 (libcap2 libraries are installed by default); for example libcap1-1.10-59.61.x86_64 & libcap1-32bit-1.10-59.61.x86_64
ksh is replaced by mksh; that is mksh-50-2.13.x86_64
libaio has been renamed to libaio1 (that is libaio1-0.3.109-17.15.x86_64); ensure that libaio1 is installed
OUI may be invoked with -ignoreSysPreqs to temporarily workaround ongoing CVU check failures
